questions.text: A female presents with hypopigmented round lesion in the middle of forehead. It is caused by which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Para Tertiary Butyl Phenol. Explanation for Correct Answer: Para Tertiary Butyl Phenol (PTBP) is a known depigmenting agent and a common cause of occupational leukoderma or chemical leukoderma, where hypopigmented patches appear due to exposure to certain chemicals. PTBP is commonly found in industrial chemicals, rubber products, and adhesives. In this case, the hypopigmented round lesion on the forehead could have resulted from contact with PTBP-containing products like cosmetics, adhesive bindis, or other personal care products. PTBP causes depigmentation by inhibiting melanin production in melanocytes, leading to localized depigmentation at the site of exposure. Explanation for Incorrect Options: A. Hydroquinone is incorrect because hydroquinone is a depigmenting agent used in the treatment of melasma and other hyperpigmented conditions. It is not a primary cause of chemical leukoderma unless misused or overused. Hydroquinone usually causes diffuse depigmentation rather than isolated, round lesions like in this case. B. Mono Benzyl Ether of Hydroquinone is incorrect because while it can cause depigmentation, it is primarily used in the treatment of vitiligo to depigment the surrounding normal skin to achieve uniformity. It is unlikely to cause isolated lesions like the one described unless applied intentionally to a specific area. D. Para Tertiary Butyl Catechol is incorrect because although it is a chemical with depigmenting properties and may cause occupational leukoderma, it is less commonly implicated in lesions on the face. It is primarily found in industrial products like rubber and dyes, and exposure is more likely to affect areas that come in frequent contact with these substances, such as hands or arms.

Correct Answer (A) Absent melanocytes. Explanation for Correct Answer: Vitiligo is characterized by the absence of melanocytes in the affected areas of the skin, leading to depigmented macules or patches. This occurs due to the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes, where the body’s immune system mistakenly targets and destroys these pigment-producing cells. The absence of melanocytes results in a lack of melanin production, causing the characteristic white patches. Histological studies confirm the absence or near absence of melanocytes in affected areas, while unaffected skin retains normal melanocyte density. Explanation for Incorrect Options: B. Defective enzyme tyrosinase is incorrect because tyrosinase deficiency is associated with albinism, not vitiligo. In albinism, melanocytes are present, but they are unable to produce melanin due to a defect in the tyrosinase enzyme. In vitiligo, the issue is the absence of melanocytes, not defective enzyme function. C. Defective migration of melanocytes is incorrect because defective migration of melanocytes occurs during embryogenesis and is associated with conditions like piebaldism and Waardenburg syndrome. Vitiligo, however, is an acquired disorder where melanocytes are destroyed after normal development and distribution. D. External chemical destruction of melanocytes is incorrect because while external chemicals can cause chemical leukoderma, this is a different condition. Vitiligo is primarily caused by autoimmune mechanisms, not external chemical factors. However, certain chemicals may act as triggers in genetically predisposed individuals.

questions.text: A patient comes into the clinic with a unilateral blue-brown speckled patch involving her malar face. A biopsy shows an increased number of elongated, dendritic melanocytes scattered throughout the dermis, and normal collagen pattern. Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nevus of Ota. Explanation for Correct Answer: Nevus of Ota is characterized by a unilateral blue-brown speckled patch, commonly involving the malar region of the face, along with other areas supplied by the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. Histologically, it shows an increased number of elongated, dendritic melanocytes scattered within the dermis, which aligns with the findings described in the biopsy. These melanocytes produce melanin, leading to the bluish-brown discoloration due to the Tyndall effect, where light scatters as it passes through the dermis. This condition is congenital but can become more noticeable with age. Explanation for Incorrect Options: B. Blue nevus is incorrect because a blue nevus is typically a small, well-circumscribed, bluish lesion. While it also involves melanocytes in the dermis, it does not present as a large, speckled patch covering the malar region. The lesion is often localized and does not have the diffuse and patchy distribution seen in Nevus of Ota. C. Hypomelanosis of Ito is incorrect because it is a condition of hypopigmentation, characterized by streaks, whorls, or patches of lighter skin, not blue-brown patches. It is often associated with systemic anomalies, such as neurologic or musculoskeletal abnormalities, which are not described in this patient. D. Sturge-Weber syndrome is incorrect because it is associated with a port-wine stain (nevus flammeus) due to vascular malformations, usually following the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. It does not involve dermal melanocytes or present with blue-brown pigmentation. Additionally, it often has associated neurological and ocular complications, such as glaucoma and seizures, which are not mentioned here.

questions.text: A 29 years old female presents with blotchy hyperpigmentation on cheeks & nose. She developed them during pregnancy. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chloasma. Explanation for Correct Answer: Chloasma, also known as melasma, is a condition characterized by blotchy hyperpigmentation, typically involving the cheeks, nose, forehead, and upper lip. It is common in women and is often associated with hormonal changes such as those occurring during pregnancy (hence the term "mask of pregnancy") or with the use of oral contraceptives. The condition is exacerbated by sun exposure, as ultraviolet (UV) radiation stimulates melanocytes to produce more melanin. The clinical presentation described here—a pregnant woman with hyperpigmentation on the face—is classic for chloasma. Explanation for Incorrect Options: A. Senile lentigenes are incorrect because these are age-related pigmented spots that appear due to chronic sun exposure over time. They are more common in older individuals and are not associated with hormonal changes or pregnancy. B. Freckles are incorrect because freckles (ephelides) are small, flat, brownish spots on sun-exposed skin, typically appearing during childhood. They are not associated with pregnancy or hormonal changes and do not present as blotchy hyperpigmentation. C. Nevi are incorrect because they are localized proliferations of melanocytes, presenting as well-defined pigmented lesions. Nevi are not hormonally induced and do not typically present as widespread blotchy hyperpigmentation on the face.

Correct Answer (C) Melanocytes are absent. Explanation for Correct Answer: In vitiligo, the primary pathological mechanism is the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes in the affected areas of the skin. As a result, the melanocytes are completely absent in the depigmented patches. Without melanocytes, melanin synthesis cannot occur, leading to the characteristic white or hypopigmented patches of vitiligo. Histological examination of vitiligo lesions confirms the absence of melanocytes, while surrounding unaffected skin retains normal melanocyte density. Explanation for Incorrect Options: A. Melanin synthesis is reduced is incorrect because the issue in vitiligo is not a reduction in melanin production but the complete absence of melanocytes in the patches. Reduced melanin synthesis may occur in other conditions like albinism or post-inflammatory hypopigmentation. B. Tyrosinase is genetically absent is incorrect because tyrosinase absence is a feature of albinism, not vitiligo. In albinism, melanocytes are present, but they cannot synthesize melanin due to a genetic defect in the tyrosinase enzyme. D. Melanocytes are reduced is incorrect because in vitiligo, melanocytes are not merely reduced in number but are entirely absent from the affected patches. Conditions with reduced melanocytes include certain types of post-inflammatory hypopigmentation or partial depigmentation.

questions.text: A 23 year old lady develops brown macular lesions over bridge of nose and cheeks following exposure to light. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Melasma. Explanation for Correct Answer: Melasma is a common hyperpigmentation disorder characterized by brown macular lesions predominantly affecting sun-exposed areas such as the bridge of the nose, cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is most commonly seen in young women and is often triggered by hormonal changes (e.g., pregnancy, oral contraceptives) and UV light exposure. The lesions are usually symmetric and aggravated by sunlight, which fits the clinical scenario described in the question. The pigmentation results from increased melanin production by hyperactive melanocytes stimulated by UV radiation. Explanation for Incorrect Options: B. Rosacea is incorrect because rosacea typically presents with erythema, flushing, papules, and pustules over the central face rather than brown macules. While it can involve the cheeks and nose, it does not cause pigmentation changes like melasma. C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is incorrect because while malar rash in SLE can involve the cheeks and bridge of the nose, it is erythematous, not brown or hyperpigmented. Additionally, SLE rashes are usually associated with systemic symptoms like joint pain, fatigue, or photosensitivity, which are not mentioned here. D. Photodermatitis is incorrect because it typically causes redness, itching, and inflammation rather than brown macular hyperpigmentation. While UV exposure can trigger photodermatitis, its presentation differs significantly from melasma.

questions.text: Skin pigmentation is caused by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone. Explanation for Correct Answer: Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH) is an agent known to cause depigmentation rather than pigmentation. It selectively destroys melanocytes and is often used in the treatment of widespread vitiligo to depigment the remaining pigmented skin, ensuring a uniform appearance. MBEH does not cause increased pigmentation but instead reduces melanin production, leading to lighter skin. Explanation for Incorrect Options: B. Dactinomycin is incorrect because this chemotherapeutic agent is associated with hyperpigmentation, particularly in areas exposed to sunlight or pressure. It can induce pigmentation changes due to its effects on melanocytes and skin sensitivity. C. Cyclophosphamide is incorrect because this alkylating agent can lead to diffuse or localized pigmentation of the skin, nails, or mucosa as a side effect. The exact mechanism is unclear but may involve melanocyte stimulation or deposition of drug metabolites. D. Busulphan is incorrect because it is a chemotherapeutic agent known to cause hyperpigmentation, often presenting as a diffuse darkening of the skin. The pigmentation is thought to result from the stimulation of melanocytes or accumulation of drug-related compounds in the skin.

questions.text: A female with BMI-30kg/m2 presented with following picture. This is associated with?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Acanthosis nigricans is a condition that causes areas of dark, thick velvety skin in body folds and creases. It typically affects the armpits, groin and neck. Acanthosis nigricans tends to affect people with obesity.hence,it is seen in metabolic syndrome. Option B-Addison’s disease can present with dark hyperpigmented gums and palmar creases. Option C-Hypothyroidism is often associated with vitiligo. Option D-Parathyroid disease can cause metastatic calcification in skin.

questions.text: Identify the disorder depicted in the image below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Vitiligo causes your skin to lose color or pigmentation. Smooth white or light areas called macules or patches appear on your skin. It generally starts on your hands, forearms, feet and face.But there will be no history of application of any chemical. Option B-Piebaldism refers to the absence of mature melanin-forming cells (melanocytes) in certain areas of the skin and hair.Common characteristics include a congenital white forelock, scattered normal pigmented and hypopigmented macules and a triangular shaped depigmented patch on the forehead. Option C-Albinism is a rare genetic condition caused by mutations, or changes, of certain genes that affect the amount of melanin your body produces. Melanin controls the pigmentation (color) of your skin, eyes and hair. People with albinism have extremely pale skin, eyes and hair. Option D-In bindi, there is an adhesive known as PTBP (Paratertiary butyl phenol). This chemical results in localised depigmentation of region, known as contact leukoderma.

questions.text: Velvety hyperpigmentation on flexural area of individual suffering from diabetes as shown in the Image. Identify the lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-A Becker naevus is a late-onset epidermal nevus characterised by a large brown patch with hairs on shoulder region. Option B-Acanthosis nigricans is a condition that causes areas of dark, thick velvety skin in body folds and creases. It typically affects the armpits, groin and neck. Acanthosis nigricans tends to affect people with obesity. Option C- lichen planus often appears as purple, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks. In the mouth and genital mucosa, lichen planus forms lacy white patches. Option D-Erythrasma is a skin condition caused by the normal skin bacteria Corynebacterium minutissimum.Erythrasma presents as well-defined pink or brown patches

questions.text: A patient presented with the following lesion. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Hypomelanosis of Ito is a rare condition characterized by distinctive skin changes, in which areas of the body lack skin color (hypopigmentation) especially in shoulder region. Option B-Vitiligo (segmental) is depigmentation along a dermatome,that do not cross midline. Option C-Nevus of ito is another name for Hypomelanosis of ito. Option D-Becker’s nevus is hyperpigmented with hairs on it.

questions.text: Patient presenting with joint pain and mild fever. NSAIDs were prescribed by the doctor. later,he Developed pigmentation after 1 week on the tip of the nose. What may be the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Melasma won't have joint pain and mild fever. Option B-Dengue do not cause hyperpigmentation. Option C-The given history of fever and joint pain along with centrofacial hyperpigmentation shown in the image points towards diagnosis of chickungunya. Hyperpigmentation association with chickungunya fever is macular and most commonly affects the nose and the cheeks. Nose hyperpigmentation is striking in cases of Chickungunya fever and is termed as chik sign . Option D-Fixed drug eruption won't have joint pain and mild fever.

questions.text: A female comes with unilateral lesions as shown in the image. She also has Leucotrichia. The diagnosis is likely to be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Segmental vitiligo :Hypopigmented lesions on a dermatomal pattern, not crossing midline, on a single segment. Option B-Focal vitiligo : small depigmented lesions, seen on more than 1 side, seen on both the sides, irrespective of midline. Option C-Piebaldism :genetic condition seen in children characterised by white forelock and islands of hypopigmentation. Option D-Nevus depigmentosus: Congenital defect in melanocyte migration characterised by Hypopigmented patch with serrated margin.

questions.text: A 13 year old Obese girl presented with velvety plaque on the neck as shown, Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Acanthosis nigricans is a condition that causes areas of dark, thick velvety skin in body folds and creases. It typically affects the armpits, groin and neck. Acanthosis nigricans tends to affect people with obesity. Option B-Cushing's syndrome presents with buffalo hump on the back of neck with central obesity and thin extremities.

questions.text: Which type of vitiligo is stable?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stable vitiligo was defined as having no new lesions and no progression of existing lesions for at least 2 years While unstable vitiligo was defined as new lesions or progression of existing lesions over the past 6 weeks. As for disease inactivity, segmental vitiligo usually becomes inactive after the disease has been stable for 2 years; however, non-segmental vitiligo is prone to reactivation, even after prolonged periods of stability.
